5.  Data Storage Security
Data storage security initially began when computer rooms were created. The room
was an area that was air conditioned, had waterless fire extinguishing systems, and
was physically locked. The computers were visible, but not accessible.
Now, the computers are accessible, but measures are taken so the information they
contain is not visible. The information, or data, must be changed to a form that only
you can see. This is the definition of encryption. When you can see and use the
data because you have the “encryption key” you have decrypted the data.
Storage systems provide security to the physical disk system using various
methods. One form is called file-level encryption. This method of encryption
safeguards individuals files only. One drawback is that if other information is on the
system, it may not be protected such as unallocated space or paging files.
Another form is called full disk encryption. It safeguard the information on the entire
disk or logical volume. This method includes the operating system, temporary files,
and unallocated space.
There are many tools you can use to provide file-level and full disk encryption. These
include, but are not limited to, AxCrypt, Boxcryptor, Cryptomator, EncFS, VeraCrypt,
and many others.
